Award.AwardTitle: Morphological and Phylogenetic Diversification of the Muroid Rodents
Award.AbstractNarration:
Understanding how diversity of life on earth grows is a fundamental goal of evolutionary biology. To address this essential question, this research will: (1) build an evolutionary tree (phylogeny) for muroid rodents (the most diverse and successful group of mammals) using DNA sequence data from 550 muroid species, (2) conduct anatomical studies of the skulls of those species using 3D imaging tools, and (3) combine the anatomical results with the phylogenetic results to determine when and where different lineages diversify, in terms of numbers of species and modifications of the skull and dentition. The results will determine which mechanisms - adaptation, colonization of new areas, or changes in inherent "evolvability" - cause diversity to increase.

This research will also have broad utility to the biomedical sciences because the muroid rodents include most of the species used in biomedical research (e.g., mouse, rat, hamster). Understanding their evolutionary history can profoundly change how we interpret those studies. The phylogeny will also serve as a road map for choosing new species for biomedical studies. In addition, the research team will train several post-doctoral researchers, graduate students, undergraduate students, and high school students in DNA sequencing, morphological analysis, and phylogenetics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The muroid rodents include many of the most familiar rodent species (including mice, rats, hamster, and gerbils), as well as numerous unfamiliar forms among their 1,600 species. This ecologically and scientifically important group is relatively young and given its exceptional diversity, it has been difficult to resolve their evolutionary relationships and fully understand their evolutionary history. Our goal was to reveal the evolutionary family tree (phylogeny) using DNA sequence data (the letters of the genetic code) from a large number of species and from multiple genes. Then, this phylogeny would represent the framework for reconstructing their distributions and dispersals among all the continents except Antarctica, revealing what if any role geography played in promoting or restricting their diversification. Detailed 2-dimentional and 3-dimensional data of skull and body shape were collected for hundreds of species to discover how morphological diversity evolved during their history and in the context of their changing geography.

 

The first steps in this research program were to (1) estimate the largest and most robust phylogenies for the superfamily Muroidea, (2) revise taxonomic questions so that specimens, species, and higher taxa are accurately determined, (3) map the geographic distributions of the living species onto the phylogeny and reconstruct from this the distributions of all the ancestors, (4) measure the skulls and other morphological traits for many 2- and 3-dimensional traits to characterize their morphology, and then reconstruct how morphology has evolved, and where and when rates of morphological divergence have sped up or slowed down, and (5) combine the results of (3) and (4) to test whether evolution by adaptive radiation has played an important role in the diversification of this group. In more detail, (1), we sequenced 5 genes (4 nuclear and 1 mitochondrial) for 550 species. We then added published DNA sequences for other species to bring the total to 900 species in a single phylogeny. The resulting phylogenetic trees (an initial 300-species and the as-yet unpublished 900-species) were very robust, with high confidence values for most of the branches in the trees. Some changes to the classification of muroid rodents were made. We discovered that muroid rodents colonized continents at least 28 times. Contrary to conventional expectations that such colonizations often lead to adaptive radiations, only one (the first colonization of South America) actually showed such evidence, where there is an initial burst of speciation and morphological divergence, followed by a slow-down in both those rates as the newly available ecological niches became filled up. Focusing on South America, we also found that after muroid rodents first colonized approximately 7-9 million years ago, that they then dispersed rapidly into and among different regions, and that as the group radiated into 300 species over time, the rate of dispersal between regions slowed down, resulting in many localized radiations. We also used these data to focus on subgroups, particularly the gerbils and the forest mice of the Philippine islands. Among several findings, we demonstrated that among gerbils, which generally live in dry habitats of Africa and Asia, the auditory bullae (the capsule of bone surrounding the inner ear) enlarged dramatically in direct response to drier climates (and not necessarily to warmer habitats), perhaps to better conduct low-frequency sounds and improve hearing. Also, we discovered 7 new species in one genus of forest mice, just on the island of Luzon, the highest diversity and density of closely related mammals anywhere in the world.
